title: 106_hr1269
content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" may impose sanctions for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, including civil penalties. Sec. 109 of the "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" prohibits royalty violations, including failure to comply with requirements, make required payments, or submit false information related to royalty payments. The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" prohibits violations related to royalty payments, with penalties including triple the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, and a $25,000 civil penalty per violation per day. Reporting the violation within 30 days exempts the violator from these penalties. Lease administration violations include failure to report designations or assignments, refusal of entry, inspection, or audit, and non-compliance with specified subsections. Any person who fails to comply with lease management responsibilities, such as reporting and providing necessary records, may face a penalty of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Additionally, individuals who engage in theft of oil or gas without legal authority are subject to penalties. Any unauthorized extraction or sale of oil or gas can result in penalties of up to $25,000 per violation per day. Repeated violations will lead to a demand for compliance within 30 days. Failure to comply with the demand will result in further consequences. Any person who fails to comply with a demand for unauthorized extraction or sale of oil or gas shall be liable to the United States for a civil penalty equal to 3 times the amount of any civil penalty that otherwise applies. Additionally, repeated violations may result in production shutdown, acquisition prohibition, and payment designation restrictions. The Secretary can cancel or transfer oil or gas leases, collect reimbursement for costs, and the person can appeal the determination of royalties or penalties within 15 days. The Secretary can cancel or transfer oil or gas leases, collect reimbursement for costs, and the person can appeal the determination of royalties or penalties within 15 days. Any penalty amount can be deducted from sums owed by the United States, and the Secretary has the authority to compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties will be served personally or by registered mail, and individuals can designate a representative to receive such notices. The Secretary can cancel or transfer oil or gas leases, collect reimbursement for costs, and individuals can appeal penalties within 15 days. Penalties will be served personally or by registered mail, and a representative can receive notices. Judicial review can be sought in the United States district court within 90 days of the Secretary's final order. If a person fails to pay a civil penalty assessed under the Act and does not file for judicial review within 90 days, the court can award the amount plus interest. No liability for penalties under the Act for failure to comply with the Mineral Leasing Act. No person shall be liable for a civil penalty under the Act for failure to pay any rental for a lease automatically terminated under the Mineral Leasing Act. Any violation tolls the statute of limitations until corrected or a final order is issued. The Secretary or a designee may determine a person's violation of certain subsections, requiring them to maintain oil and gas lease records until released by the Secretary or expiration of the record retention period. Amounts received from penalties for underpayment of royalties are treated as royalties paid under the mineral leasing laws. Amounts received from penalties for underpayment of royalties are treated as royalties paid under the mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amendment to the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty.
